__ATTN__: Do not edit this file; changes belong in the appropriate YAML file.
overview:
Like partials, Parent tags are used to expand an external template into the
current template. Unlike partials, Parent tags may contain optional
arguments delimited by Block tags. For this reason, Parent tags may also be
referred to as Parametric Partials.

The Parent tags' content MUST be a non-whitespace character sequence NOT
containing the current closing delimiter; each Parent tag MUST be followed by
an End Section tag with the same content within the matching Parent tag.

This tag's content names the Parent template to inject. Set Delimiter tags
Preceding a Parent tag MUST NOT affect the parsing of the injected external
template. The Parent MUST be rendered against the context stack local to the
tag. If the named Parent cannot be found, the empty string SHOULD be used
instead, as in interpolations.

Parent tags SHOULD be treated as standalone when appropriate. If this tag is
used standalone, any whitespace preceding the tag should be treated as
indentation, and prepended to each line of the Parent before rendering.

The Block tags' content MUST be a non-whitespace character sequence NOT
containing the current closing delimiter. Each Block tag MUST be followed by
an End Section tag with the same content within the matching Block tag. This
tag's content determines the parameter or argument name.

Block tags may appear both inside and outside of Parent tags. In both cases,
they specify a position within the template that can be overridden; it is a
parameter of the containing template. The template text between the Block tag
and its matching End Section tag defines the default content to render when
the parameter is not overridden from outside.

In addition, when used inside of a Parent tag, the template text between a
Block tag and its matching End Section tag defines content that replaces the
default defined in the Parent template. This content is the argument passed
to the Parent template.

The practice of injecting an external template using a Parent tag is referred
to as inheritance. If the Parent tag includes a Block tag that overrides a
parameter of the Parent template, this may also be referred to as
substitution.

Parent templates are taken from the same namespace as regular Partial
templates and in fact, injecting a regular Partial is exactly equivalent to
injecting a Parent without making any substitutions. Parameter and arguments
names live in a namespace that is distinct from both Partials and the context.

tests.name: Default
tests.desc: Default content should be rendered if the block isn't overridden

tests.name: Variable
tests.desc: Default content renders variables

tests.name: Triple Mustache
tests.desc: Default content renders triple mustache variables

tests.name: Sections
tests.desc: Default content renders sections

tests.name: Negative Sections
tests.desc: Default content renders negative sections

tests.name: Mustache Injection
tests.desc: Mustache injection in default content

tests.name: Inherit
tests.desc: Default content rendered inside inherited templates

tests.name: Overridden content
tests.desc: Overridden content

tests.name: Data does not override block
tests.desc: Context does not override argument passed into parent

tests.name: Data does not override block default
tests.desc: Context does not override default content of block

tests.name: Overridden parent
tests.desc: Overridden parent

tests.name: Two overridden parents
tests.desc: Two overridden parents with different content

tests.name: Override parent with newlines
tests.desc: Override parent with newlines

tests.name: Inherit indentation
tests.desc: Inherit indentation when overriding a parent

tests.name: Only one override
tests.desc: Override one parameter but not the other

tests.name: Parent template
tests.desc: Parent templates behave identically to partials when called with no parameters

tests.name: Recursion
tests.desc: Recursion in inherited templates

tests.name: Multi-level inheritance
tests.desc: Top-level substitutions take precedence in multi-level inheritance

tests.name: Multi-level inheritance, no sub child
tests.desc: Top-level substitutions take precedence in multi-level inheritance

tests.name: Text inside parent
tests.desc: Ignores text inside parent templates, but does parse $ tags

tests.name: Text inside parent
tests.desc: Allows text inside a parent tag, but ignores it

tests.name: Block scope
tests.desc: Scope of a substituted block is evaluated in the context of the parent template

tests.name: Standalone parent
tests.desc: A parent's opening and closing tags need not be on separate lines in order to be standalone

tests.name: Standalone block
tests.desc: A block's opening and closing tags need not be on separate lines in order to be standalone

tests.name: Block reindentation
tests.desc: Block indentation is removed at the site of definition and added at the site of expansion

tests.name: Intrinsic indentation
tests.desc: When the block opening tag is standalone, indentation is determined by default content

tests.name: Nested block reindentation
tests.desc: Nested blocks are reindented relative to the surrounding block
